Immortal Longings: An Interview with New York Times bestselling author Chloe Gong

By Emily Warner

Emily Warner (she/her) interviews Chloe Gong about her debut adult fantasy novel Immortal Longings

Indochine

Yorkshire, oriental and tapas are not three words that go comfortably together. With the Yorkshire stereotype tending towards a mean old man with a whippet, a flat cap, and questionable dentistry, my first thought was of miniscule portions

Pesto Chicken

This baked dish is simple and colourful. It uses 'mini fillet breasts' but you can use normal sized ones and cut them into 2 inch goujons

Summer Spirit

By James Bithell

Happy Birthday luxury fashion brand Gucci who celebrate their 90th year as one of the best in the business. The look is retro chic plus uber bold colours. Creative Director Frida Giannini is implementing a new eco-friendly strategy to project the brand into the future (Thumbnail credit Photos: style.com)

Trends: Royal Ascot

Stephen Jones, Ascot's official milliner for 2011, has made an impact with his feathered orange and purple hat adorned with poppies, worn not by a lady but a filly (to non-equine followers that's a female horse)

The Jackson Aftershock

As the second anniversary of Michael Jackson's death approaches the sense of loss certainly does not seem to have lessened. There are stars, there are superstars and there are legends. Jackson was all of these and more

Last orders

It's very difficult, writing a final column. The end of term is an emotional time for everyone and the temptation to make like Gwyneth Paltrow and start snotting, weeping and generally swooning all over my mac seems all too easy

Playboy by numbers

Playboy by numbers

Camilla Jenkins investigates: The daily grind

A very wise man (the Chief in Grey's Anatomy - where I get all my top tips) explained to success-thirsty young interns that life was a marathon and, at the end of it, you don't care if you win or lose, you'll just be glad you survived

MUSEings: taking it too far

"There is a line, ok, and I won't cross it!" These self-assured words were uttered from the wise mouth of Ollie (of <em>Made in Chelsea</em> fame) to Binky (likewise) as he stood in a cold open park wearing a gold thong, holding bananas in front of his crotch

Band of the Week: Cocteau Twins

By James Bithell

Resident sound-nerd <em>Tom Killingbeck</em> thumbs through reams of musty vinyl so you don't have to. Here are his weekly recommendations...

Treasure Island

PantSoc's 2011 summer pantomime has a big, energetic cast and genuinely entertaining moments, which make you really want to discount the rather freewheeling storyline and the one-too-many deliberately groan inducing puns

Red Snow

The discordant and the beautiful set the stage at the Barn this week with James Robert Ball's debut musical. Emily Heggadon urges you to see this piece of student written theatre of the highest calibre. Rating: ****

Review: Wet Nuns

With the pretentious decor of the Harley burning onto my retinas, the bobbing shield of heads is quite the blessing. Rating: ****

Band of the Week: The Gun Club

By James Bithell

Resident sound-nerd <em>Tom Killingbeck</em> thumbs through reams of musty vinyl so you don't have to. Here are his weekly recommendations...

Lady in lace?

It's the versatility of lace that makes it such an enduring fashion staple. But how do we update lace in summer 2011? Amy Cooke gives you a few ideas (Thumbnail credit Taylor Momsen makes lace more casual)

Road

Though to coin the production as merely "different" could be seen as ambiguous and degrading, it shows how <em>Road</em> is very much a breath of fresh air, and through its novelty promenade nature, has created a highly successful performance

Much Ado About Nothing

A production that has you in its frivolous, funny and intelligent grasp from beginning to end, <em>Much Ado About Nothing</em> is undoubtedly one of the highlights of The Globe's 2011 season (Thumbnail credit Image: Tristram Kenton)

WINK

This year the Norman Rea gallery has invited York students to submit work which is intended as a wink or nod towards another artist: an intelligent pastiche that reinterprets, reinvents or reveals an interesting element of the original work

Review: Misstallica

<em>Metallica</em> tribute or not, this Philadelphian foursome is undoubtedly a force of metal to be reckoned with. Rating: ****

Band of the Week: Can

By James Bithell

Resident sound-nerd <em>Tom Killingbeck</em> thumbs through reams of musty vinyl so you don't have to. Here are his weekly recommendations...

A Midsummer Night's Dream

It cannot be said that after spending an evening in the surprising space that is the drama barn, you are left feeling as if it were merely an illusion. This production of William Shakespeare's <em>A Midsummer Night's Dream</em> was funny and chic, and most certainly concretely ingrained in the minds of the audience (Thumbnail credit Image: Greg Ebdon)

X-Men: First Class

Abandon all your preconceptions about comic book films at the door - you won't be needing them

Upcoming: The Nouse Music Summer Gig Guide

By James Bithell

Festival phobic? <em>Adam Bychawski</em> offers up some more local gig alternatives.

Taking the piss

By James Bithell

Politicians have long been the subject of ridicule. <em>Hannah Ellis-Petersen</em> talks to Steve Bell, The Guardian's political cartoonist, about the power and influence his pen has held over Thatcher, Major, and the rest of the motley ruling crew (Thumbnail credit Margaret Thatcher being escorted out of Downing Street in a straitjacket. Credit: Steve Bell)

Wannabe Hacks

<em>Jake Farrell</em> explores the extraordinary movement sweeping the journalist scene; the hacks are a new breed of legitimate reporters

Sharing the Hate

By James Bithell

<em>James Dixon</em> talks to a woman who hates soldiers, fags and the Japanese; all with the security of God behind her (Thumbnail credit Shirley Phelps at her protests)

It's just not cricket

By James Bithell

Four years on from the creation of biggest Twenty20 cricket league in the world, <em>Sam Lawson</em> looks at the pros and cons of the IPL and whether expectations of its success has marred its development (Thumbnail credit Kevin Pietersen for Royal Challengers)

Flower Power

Cliche though it may be, florals are a big yes for this summer's wardrobe. <em>Serena Kalirai</em> takes you through how to do it this time round

Trending: sunglasses

When we think of summer we think of sunglasses. When we think of designer glasses we turn to Ray-Ban. Heritage with a twist, dating back to the 1930s as binocular designers and later sunglasses specialists distributing to the US Armed forces

The Beautiful Game

Did you watch the football? It was a healthy competition, full of talented young men at a peak of physical fitness. We all remember David Beckham, Freddie Ljungberg and, my personal favourite, Didier Drogba posing in their tiny briefs, just bulging with style. Fashion and football have a relationship often overlooked
